channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-2244] forcing auto-commit on Oracle JDBC connection that is still part of a transaction breaks transactional behavior
item.description:
We found a problem with Aries managed XA transactions and Oracle JDBC.

In a nutshell, if the database raises an SQL exception within the scope of an XA exception (in our example XA transacted Camel route), the JDBC connection cleanup routine of org.tranql tries to enable auto commit on the Oracle JDBC connection, which raises an SQL exception and causes the connection to be closed.
As a result the tx rollback that happens thereafter (due to original SQL exception) fails as the underlying JDBC connection is already closed.

I managed to find the culprit in method org.tranql.connector.jdbc.ManagedXAConnection.cleanup():

// org.tranql.connector.jdbc.ManagedXAConnection.cleanup()
 
public void cleanup() throws ResourceException {
 
       super.cleanup();
 
       Connection c = physicalConnection;
 
       try {
 
           //TODO reset tx isolation level
 
           if (!c.getAutoCommit()) {
 
               c.setAutoCommit(true);       <—————— 
           }
 
       } catch (SQLException e) {
 
           throw new ResourceException("Could not reset autocommit when returning to pool", e);
 
       }
 
   }

Calling c.setAutoCommit(true) on the Oracle JDBC connection raises:

"java.sql.SQLException: could not turn on auto-commit in an active global transaction"

Everything else is a follow up of this problem. The JDBC connection gets closed and later attempts to rollback the tx raises 

"java.sql.SQLRecoverableException: Closed Connection”

Even though Aries retries the rollback, it never succeeds as it seems to hold on to the same JDBC connection that remains closed.
So the rollback functionality does not work properly when using Oracle ojdbc6 drivers [1].

It seems the call to c.setAutoCommit(true) is wrong at this stage. The error thrown seems reasonable 

"java.sql.SQLException: could not turn on auto-commit in an active global transaction"

I can happily share a test case.
item.summary: forcing auto-commit on Oracle JDBC connection that is still part of a transaction breaks transactional behavior

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I can provide a full test case but in essence I use the following blueprint definition

 <bean id="oracle-ds" class="oracle.jdbc.xa.client.OracleXADataSource">
 
   <property name="URL" value="jdbc:oracle:thin:@myhost:1521:orcl"/>
 
   <property name="user" value="tmielke"/>
 
   <property name="password" value="tmielke"/>
 
 </bean>
 
 
 
 <service interface="javax.sql.XADataSource" ref="oracle-ds">
 
   <service-properties>
 
           <entry key="osgi.jndi.service.name" value="jdbc/oracle"/>
 
           <entry key="datasource.name" value="oracle-ds"/>
 
           <entry key="aries.xa.pooling" value="true" />
 
           <entry key="aries.xa.poolMinSize" value="1" />
 
           <entry key="aries.xa.poolMaxSize" value="5" />
 
           <entry key="aries.xa.name" value="oracle-ds" />
 
           <entry key="aries.xa.username" value="tmielke"/>
 
           <entry key="aries.xa.password" value="tmielke"/>
 
   </service-properties>
 
 </service>

Call stack that leads to calling c.setAutoCommit(true):

Daemon Thread [Camel (camel-1) thread #4 - JmsConsumer[JDBC_IN]] (Suspended)	
	org.tranql.connector.jdbc.ManagedXAConnection.cleanup() line: 143	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.SinglePoolConnectionInterceptor(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.AbstractSinglePoolConnectionInterceptor).internalReturn(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionInfo, org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionReturnAction) line: 151	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.SinglePoolConnectionInterceptor(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.AbstractSinglePoolConnectionInterceptor).returnConnection(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionInfo, org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionReturnAction) line: 129	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.TransactionEnlistingInterceptor.returnConnection(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionInfo, org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionReturnAction) line: 113	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.TransactionCachingInterceptor.returnConnection(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionInfo, org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionReturnAction) line: 119	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionHandleInterceptor.returnConnection(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionInfo, org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionReturnAction) line: 71	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.TCCLInterceptor.returnConnection(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionInfo, org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionReturnAction) line: 50	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionTrackingInterceptor.returnConnection(org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionInfo, org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.ConnectionReturnAction) line: 91	
	org.apache.geronimo.connector.outbound.GeronimoConnectionEventListener.connectionErrorOccurred(javax.resource.spi.ConnectionEvent) line: 95	
	org.tranql.connector.jdbc.ManagedXAConnection(org.tranql.connector.AbstractManagedConnection<T,U>).unfilteredConnectionError(java.lang.Exception) line: 126	
	org.tranql.connector.jdbc.ManagedXAConnection(org.tranql.connector.AbstractManagedConnection<T,U>).connectionError(java.lang.Exception) line: 115	
	org.tranql.connector.jdbc.ConnectionHandle.connectionError(java.sql.SQLException) line: 112	
	org.tranql.connector.jdbc.StatementHandle<T>.execute(java.lang.String) line: 121	
	org.apache.camel.component.jdbc.JdbcProducer.doCreateAndExecuteSqlStatement(org.apache.camel.Exchange, java.lang.String, java.sql.Connection) line: 183	
	org.apache.camel.component.jdbc.JdbcProducer.createAndExecuteSqlStatement(org.apache.camel.Exchange, java.lang.String, java.sql.Connection) line: 118	
	org.apache.camel.component.jdbc.JdbcProducer.processingSqlWithoutSettingAutoCommit(org.apache.camel.Exchange) line: 108	
	org.apache.camel.component.jdbc.JdbcProducer.process(org.apache.camel.Exchange) line: 68	
	org.apache.camel.util.AsyncProcessorConverterHelper$ProcessorToAsyncProcessorBridge.process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback) line: 61	
	org.apache.camel.processor.SendProcessor.process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback) line: 110	
	org.apache.camel.management.InstrumentationProcessor.process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback) line: 72	
	org.apache.camel.processor.DefaultErrorHandler(org.apache.camel.processor.RedeliveryErrorHandler).process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback) line: 398	
	org.apache.camel.processor.interceptor.DefaultChannel(org.apache.camel.processor.CamelInternalProcessor).process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback) line: 191	
	org.apache.camel.processor.Pipeline.process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback, java.util.Iterator<org.apache.camel.Processor>, org.apache.camel.AsyncProcessor) line: 118	
	org.apache.camel.processor.Pipeline.process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback) line: 80	
	org.apache.camel.processor.CamelInternalProcessor.process(org.apache.camel.Exchange, org.apache.camel.AsyncCallback) line: 191	
	org.apache.camel.util.AsyncProcessorHelper.process(org.apache.camel.AsyncProcessor, org.apache.camel.Exchange) line: 105	
	org.apache.camel.processor.CamelInternalProcessor(org.apache.camel.processor.DelegateAsyncProcessor).process(org.apache.camel.Exchange) line: 87	
	org.apache.camel.component.jms.EndpointMessageListener.onMessage(javax.jms.Message) line: 103	
	org.apache.camel.component.jms.DefaultJmsMessageListenerContainer(org.springframework.jms.listener.AbstractMessageListenerContainer).doInvokeListener(javax.jms.MessageListener, javax.jms.Message) line: 562	
	org.apache.camel.component.jms.DefaultJmsMessageListenerContainer(org.springframework.jms.listener.AbstractMessageListenerContainer).invokeListener(javax.jms.Session, javax.jms.Message) line: 500	
	org.apache.camel.component.jms.DefaultJmsMessageListenerContainer(org.springframework.jms.listener.AbstractMessageListenerContainer).doExecuteListener(javax.jms.Session, javax.jms.Message) line: 468	
	org.apache.camel.component.jms.DefaultJmsMessageListenerContainer(org.springframework.jms.listener.AbstractPollingMessageListenerContainer).doReceiveAndExecute(java.lang.Object, javax.jms.Session, javax.jms.MessageConsumer, org.springframework.transaction.TransactionStatus) line: 325	
	org.apache.camel.component.jms.DefaultJmsMessageListenerContainer(org.springframework.jms.listener.AbstractPollingMessageListenerContainer).receiveAndExecute(java.lang.Object, javax.jms.Session, javax.jms.MessageConsumer) line: 243	
	org.springframework.jms.listener.DefaultMessageListenerContainer$AsyncMessageListenerInvoker.invokeListener() line: 1101	
	org.springframework.jms.listener.DefaultMessageListenerContainer$AsyncMessageListenerInvoker.executeOngoingLoop() line: 1093	
	org.springframework.jms.listener.DefaultMessageListenerContainer$AsyncMessageListenerInvoker.run() line: 990	
	java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker) line: 1145	
	java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run() line: 615	
	java.lang.Thread.run() line: 744

I also played with resetAutoCommit property on the Camel JDBC component config but it has no effect because the XA conn already has autoCommit disabled. The Camel code simply checks if its enabled and then disables it.
Since its disabled we execute this code shown above

if (!c.getAutoCommit()) {
 
  c.setAutoCommit(true);
 
}

I also tested with MySQL and did not hit the issue because the call to 

if (!c.getAutoCommit()) {

evaluated to false.
For MySQL I pass in relaxAutoCommit=true on the JDBC url as well. This could have an impact.
Did not find any equivalent switch when using Oracle JDBC driver.

For clarity, this MySQL config works fine:

<bean id="mysql-ds" class="com.mysql.jdbc.jdbc2.optional.MysqlXADataSource">
 
    <property name="databaseName" value="test"/>
 
    <property name="url" value="jdbc:mysql://localhost/test?relaxAutoCommit=true" />
 
    <property name="user" value="root"/>
 
    <property name="password" value=""/>
 
  </bean> 
 
 
  <service interface="javax.sql.XADataSource" ref="mysql-ds">
 
    <service-properties>
 
      <entry key="osgi.jndi.service.name" value="jdbc/mysqldb"/>
 
      <entry key="datasource.name" value="MySQL"/>
 
      <entry key="aries.xa.pooling" value="true" />
 
      <entry key="aries.xa.poolMinSize" value="0" />
 
      <entry key="aries.xa.poolMaxSize" value="5" />
 
      <entry key="aries.xa.name" value="mysqlDS" />
 
    </service-properties>
 
  </service>

Am testing the fix as part of 6.1 R1 patch but believe there may still be a follow up problem.
The original problem with the auto-commit is fixed, I can confirm that.

However there is still a problem further down in the processing.
So with the fix camel-jdbc catches the SQLException and initiates a tx rollback.

This however results in 

"java.sql.SQLException: Failed lazy association with ManagedConnection"

most likely caused by 

Caused by: java.sql.SQLRecoverableException: Closed Connection

as the connection got closed by tranql as part of the SQLException.
As a result there should probably be a pending XA transaction dangling in the database.

We managed to overcome this behavior by adding an exception sorter to the wrapped jdbc driver:

  <service interface="javax.sql.XADataSource" ref="oracle-ds">
 
    <service-properties>
 
            <entry key="osgi.jndi.service.name" value="jdbc/oracle"/>
 
            <entry key="datasource.name" value="oracle-ds"/>
 
            <entry key="aries.xa.pooling" value="true" />
 
            <entry key="aries.xa.poolMinSize" value="1" />
 
            <entry key="aries.xa.poolMaxSize" value="5" />
 
            <entry key="aries.xa.name" value="oracle-ds" />
 
            <entry key="aries.xa.username" value="tmielke"/>
 
            <entry key="aries.xa.password" value="tmielke"/>
 
            <!-- careful about this config, which treats all exceptions as recoverable-->
 
            <entry key="aries.xa.exceptionSorter" value="none" />
 
    </service-properties>
 
  </service>

How should this behave?
Do we rely on an exceptionSorter (more fine grained config of course) to be present in the config above so that this use case works properly and correctly rolls back the tx? This will be very difficult for users to configure correctly I am afraid.

See this comment under ENTESB-2047.

IMO, none value of aries.xa.exceptionSorter is way better than all option, as it's not that much against JDBC specification (chapter 8.5.1 of JDBC 4.0 specification):

After a NonTransient SQLException other than SQLNonTransientConnectionException occurs, the application can assume that the connection is still valid.

the same behavior is implemented for example in PostgreSQL driver:

    // Classes we consider fatal.
 
    private static String[] fatalClasses = {
 
        "08",  // connection error
 
        "53",  // insufficient resources
 
 
 
        // nb: not just "57" as that includes query cancel which is nonfatal
 
        "57P01",  // admin shutdown
 
        "57P02",  // crash shutdown
 
        "57P03",  // cannot connect now
 
 
 
        "58",  // system error (backend)
 
        "60",  // system error (driver)
 
        "99",  // unexpected error
 
        "F0",  // configuration file error (backend)
 
        "XX",  // internal error (backend)
 
    };

For Fuse 6.2 we need new minor release of org.apache.aries.transaction:org.apache.aries.transaction.jdbc - it'll be 2.1.1.

Guillaume Nodet Are you able to do aries releases?
